SELECTED TOPICS IN ENGLISH Special Subject: MODERN ARABIC FICTION

This course examines key developments in Arabic fiction in the contemporary Arabic-speaking world with the aim of highlighting the distinctive texture of its experiences and identities. The chosen texts cover a wide range of topics and convey the complex and rich cultural diversity of the Arab World. The course is taught in English and no prior knowledge of the Arabic language is required. NOTE: This course is also given as ENGL 398F.

SELECTED TOPICS IN ENGLISH Special Subject: DON QUIXOTE

This course is also given as ENGL 398Y - Imperial Fictions: Don Quixote in the New World Order. This course proposes a reading of Miguel de Cervantes’s seventeenth-century novels Don Quixote I and II as they relate to Spain’s nation and empire building project in early modernity. In addition to the close reading of selected chapters and passages from the novels, the course will include theoretical and critical readings from recent and current debates concerning the place of literature in baroque Spain’s transition towards modernity. Cervantes’s complex treatment of ethnic violence and gender identity will also be brought to bear on current ideological and political debates. Course requirements will include short analytical essays, small group participation and a final analytical essay. English program students will read the novels and write their essays in English. Spanish program students will read the novels and write their essays in Spanish. Class discussions will be conducted in English.

Department Note (Summer) for FRAN :FRENCH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE
All students not admitted into a programme in the Département d'études françaises are required to take a placement test in order to determine the level of elective French courses for which they can obtain credit(please consult the Études françaises web site for placement test information).
NOTE : FRAN 211 is restricted to students with no previous training in French. FRAN 212 is designed to follow FRAN 211, or may be taken if students have a little previous training in French. FRAN 211 AND 212 are not intended for students who have attended high school in Quebec.
Some students with previous French language background are restricted to certain levels of French language courses at Concordia. These restrictions will be indicated as «exemptions» on your transcript. Apart from any exemptions which may have been granted to undergraduate students, the following restrictions apply to ALL students.
1)at Concordia. No credit will be awarded for language courses numbered 211-221.

Department Note (FallWinter) for FRAN :FRENCH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE
All students not admitted into a programme in the Département d'études françaises are required to take a placement test in order to determine the level of elective French courses for which they can obtain credit (consult the Études françaises web site for placement test information).
NOTE : FRAN 211 is restricted to students with no previous training in French. FRAN 212 is designed to follow FRAN 211, or may be taken if students have a little previous training in French. FRAN 211 AND 212 are not intended for students who have attended high school in Quebec.
Some students with previous French language background are restricted to certain levels of French language courses at Concordia. These restrictions will be indicated as «exemptions» on your transcript. Apart from any exemptions which may have been granted to undergraduate students, the following restrictions apply to ALL students.
1)Students who have completed any 602-900 level CEGEP courses or who graduated from Francophone secondary institutions may obtain a maximum of 6 credits in the range of FRAN 301-321 at Concordia. No credit will be awarded for language courses numbered 211-221.
2) Students who have completed any 601-series CEGEP courses OR who have attended a Francophone CEGEP may ONLY obtain credits for Concordia French Language courses at the 400-level (FRAA 400-441). No credit will be awarded for language courses numbered 211-221 or 301-321.

SELECTED TOPICS IN GERMAN Special Subject: GERMAN THROUGH FILM

This course is designed for content-based instruction, making learning the German language meaningful and enjoyable. It is based on contemporary German films. A wide variety of exercises, pre-viewing, viewing, and post-viewing activities, will enhance the understanding of German culture and contemporary society through analysis of social and cultural issues. At the same time it will foster vocabulary enhancement, cultural awareness, oral discussion, and essay writing. This course will be taught in German.

SELECTED TOPICS IN ITALIAN Special Subject: CONT MIGR WRITERS IN ITALY

Contemporary Migrant Writers in Italy. This course offers an historical and theoretical introduction to migration literature in Italy. The course examines a selection of texts from authors such as Salah Methnani, Pap Khouma, Igiaba Scego, Amara Lakhous, and many other contemporary writers who, in their works, discuss the representation and integration of migrants in Italian society and address issues of postcoloniality and national identity. The language of instruction is English, and no prior knowledge of the Italian language is required. Advanced level students—i.e., students placed at the 300-level or higher in Italian—must hand in all their work in Italian.

SPECIAL TOPICS IN ARABIC Special Subject: MODERN ARABIC FICTION

This course examines key developments in Arabic fiction in the contemporary Arabic-speaking world with the aim of highlighting the distinctive texture of its experiences and identities. The chosen texts cover a wide range of topics and convey the complex and rich cultural diversity of the Arab World. The course is taught in English and no prior knowledge of the Arabic language is required. NOTE: This course is also given as ENGL 398F.
SPECIAL TOPICS IN ARABIC Special Subject: MARA FOR HERITAGE SPKS I

This course provides an introduction to the basic elements of Modern Standard Arabic for students with basic or limited knowledge of the language. It is designed for heritage speakers with no reading and writing skills of Modern Standard Arabic but with knowledge of dialect vocabulary and oral skills. The course is also for non-heritage students who know the Arabic script but have never learned the Arabic language.

SPECIAL TOPICS IN SPANISH PHONOLOGY SPAN

The field of phonology and phonetics has as its primary goal the description of the sounds produced in the world’s languages.Second, students will work with speech samples from speakers of several varieties of Spanish, learning to analyze and recognize the phonological and phonetic characteristics behind three of the biggest dialectal groups in the Spanish speaking world. This part of the course will expose students to speech samples from a broad group of native-speakers improving their own perceptive skills. This course will be taught entirely in Spanish.

ADVANCED TOPICS IN SPANISH Special Subject: DON QUIXOTE
SPAN 303 and 310, or permission of the Department.

This course is also given as ENGL 398Y - Imperial Fictions: Don Quixote in the New World Order. This course proposes a reading of Miguel de Cervantes’s seventeenth-century novels Don Quixote I and II as they relate to Spain’s nation and empire building project in early modernity. In addition to the close reading of selected chapters and passages from the novels, the course will include theoretical and critical readings from recent and current debates concerning the place of literature in baroque Spain’s transition towards modernity. Cervantes’s complex treatment of ethnic violence and gender identity will also be brought to bear on current ideological and political debates. Course requirements will include short analytical essays, small group participation and a final analytical essay. English program students will read the novels and write their essays in English. Spanish program students will read the novels and write their essays in Spanish. Class discussions will be conducted in English.
ADVANCED TOPICS IN SPANISH Special Subject: INTRO TO SPANISH LINGUISTICS
SPAN 303 previously or concurrently; or equivalent.

This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and analytical techniques of Linguistics, applied specifically to the Spanish language. It will cover the main areas of Hispanic Linguistics, including phonetics and phonology, morphology and syntax of the Spanish language. It may also cover topics related to semantics, pragmatics, dialectology, sociolinguistics and second language acquisition of Spanish. Activities in the course will include linguistic analysis of the sounds, words and sentences of Spanish, as well as comparisons to the structure of English and/or French when applicable. This course provides the basis for further study in the field.
